Hi there, howâ€™s it going? This is the second time to write the entry in English for me.

Anyway, do you know or have you ever used the .gitattributes file in package distribution in GitHub using its Release feature?
OK, for those people who donâ€™t/havenâ€™t that, let me explain a brief.
This is the meta data file where you can add some attributes to the files version-controlled by Git.

What the attributes are

The Official Git document descripting attributes is providing us the nice example, saying:

Using attributes, you can do things like specify separate merge strategies for individual files or directories in your project, tell Git how to diff non-text files, or have Git filter content before you check it into or out of Git.

Thatâ€™s easier to figure out. For example, if you write down yourÂ .gitattributesÂ like this:

config.yml merge=ours

Itâ€™s using a merge attribute forÂ config.ymlÂ to tell Git what the merge driver to be used for the file. In this case, itâ€™sÂ our.Â ourÂ doesnâ€™t make any sense but just the name of the driver. Of course, originally you may donâ€™t have the driver namedÂ ourÂ I guess. So following configuration is needed to run this magic:

$ git config --global merge.ours.driver true

Thatâ€™s it. Now the driverÂ ourÂ is specified asÂ true.Â trueÂ is built-in command just returning exit-codeÂ 0Â with doing nothing.
So the conclusion is when you merge some branch into your branch, your changes applied toÂ config.ymlÂ is always adapted to ship to a commit even though any conflicts with other branch occurs, with no confirmation.

For example, this may be useful the situation where you fork some nice repository and maintain it your own but you don’t want to apply any changes to the specific file (config.yml) during even back-porting changes for the original which happens sometimes.

Also, the attributes can also be applied to the directory, in that case, the attributes should apply to subfiles in the directory.

Moreover, there are many other kinds of attributes in Git, but I donâ€™t pick them up anymore for keeping my topic (other than one Iâ€™ll share you below). So check the document out if you’re interested ğŸ™‚

export-ignore attribute

So Git also has an attributeÂ export-ignore. The files which are applied this attribute shouldÂ NOTÂ be included in archive.

For example:

/tests export-ignore
README.md export-ignore

This prevents theÂ /testÂ directory andÂ README.mdÂ from including to the archive. The archive? The one which can be generated by:

$ git archive HEAD --worktree-attributes --output=/tmp/repo.zip

TIP: donâ€™t forgetÂ --worktree-attributesÂ command option. Although itâ€™s not necessary, the exclusion doesnâ€™t work if you donâ€™t specify it.

Itâ€™s good and useful, isnâ€™t it? In script languages such PHP, the distributed packages donâ€™t need to include the tests stuff. Nobody wants to install/deploy them to their production server.
And GitHub resources feature use this attribute to archive in their Release feature.
So thatâ€™s why you should always setup your export-ignore attribute for your package powered by GitHub Release (e.g. Packagist package for PHP).

Conclusion

  • The files specified attributeÂ export-ignoreÂ inÂ .gitattributesÂ are not to be archived
  • GitHub Release feature archives the repository using this attribute, so you can avoid shipping some unnecessary kinds like tests stuff for production
